title: "infinite loop" test can cause potential denial of service
body:
When we create an "infinite loo" test to test the **Execute** function in evm,  the evm will keep running and not output any result. If we use the crafted bytecode to attack the evm, is this a kind of denial of service?
![Screenshot from 2020-05-31 21-12-14](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13298978/83353250-cc309280-a383-11ea-8ba5-88a42e90101f.png)

#### System information

Geth version: `1.9.11`
OS & Version: Linux
bytecode = ""

inputdata = "77bb09eb00000000000000000000000063aec77a5ce6598ba14a832ef070c570db979815000000000000000000000000ecf1e4cce8f0186488cd33a0139f8230cec45ee1"

the testing output is as follows, has no output
![Screenshot from 2020-05-31 21-20-40](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13298978/83353364-a35ccd00-a384-11ea-9218-f47f0cae8760.png)

>  is this a kind of denial of service?

For Ethereum itself: No, because of `gas`. 
For a geth-node: No, because you're dossing yourself, 
For a geth-node with RPC-endpoints open to the world: Yes, unless `rpc-gascap` has been set to limit the amount of gas that an `eth_Call` can consume.
